Graphical abstract The adsorption of NO2 on Pt/BaO/γAl2O3 catalyst has been investigated by micro calorimetry at atmospheric pressure, NOx storage tests and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). The heat of adsorption of NO2 (ΔH ads (NO2)) was determined over a wide range of NOx coverages, as the catalyst was exposed to 500/900ppm NO2 in the absence/presence of 5% CO2 in the range of 423–773K. The temperature dependent changes of ΔH ads (NO2) verified the presence of energetically different NOx storage sites with different binding strength. The ΔH ads (NO2) was found to follow a linear correlation versus temperature, ranging for example from −134.5 to −178.8kJ/mol for NOx storage over Pt/BaO/γAl2O3 at 423–673K. Thus, at high temperature mostly strongly bound nitrates were formed, while at lower temperature more loosely bound species were also present. Interestingly, the heat of adsorption was higher when using higher NO2 concentration, indicating more bulk barium nitrate formation. This is consistent with the TPD data where a clear high temperature peak was visible after adsorption using 900ppm NO2 at 423 and 473K, which was not the case for 500ppm NO2. Moreover, the micro-calorimetric data also provided evidence in support of the detrimental effect of CO2 on the NOx uptake process. The heat released during the NOx storage in 500ppm NO2 +5% CO2 was determined to be significantly reduced ca. −97.8kJmol−1 at 423K, but ca. −134.5kJmol−1 without CO2. Furthermore, our results show that it is critical to measure heat of adsorption for surface compounds since they are significantly different compared to thermodynamic data for bulk materials. Keywords NOx storage/reduction NOx removal Pt/BaO/Al2O3 catalysts NO2 adsorption Micro- calorimetric measurements TPD NOx coverages Heat of NO2 adsorption 1 Introduction The need to find innovative ways to deal with exhaust emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and the high environmental standards [1] restricting the NOx emissions in particular from diesel-equipped vehicles have driven the development of different technologies of NOx reduction in oxygen rich conditions [2,3]. Thus, over the past several years, the NOx storage-reduction (NSR) technology originally developed by Toyota Motor Corporation [3–5] has received considerable attention as an economical and effective solution for catalytic abatement of NOx pollutants in excess oxygen. The typical NSR catalytic systems [6,7] consist of noble metals (Pt, Rh, Pd) for oxidation/reduction purposes, a material for storage, e.g., metal oxides like BaO (or BaCO3 in the presence of CO2, as under actual conditions), and γ-Al2O3 as high surface area support. The concept [6,7] is based on the alternating cycles of lean (abundant in oxygen) and rich (abundant in reductants such as unburned hydrocarbons, H2 and CO) regimes of the diesel-fuel vehicles. Under typical lean exhaust conditions, NO is oxidized to NO2 over precious metal sites and reversibly stored as nitrates/nitrites on the storage component and on the support material. Stored NOx species are subsequently decomposed, released and reduced to N2 during short periodic excursions to rich (i.e., net reducing) conditions. The storage ability of the NSR catalyst is thus restored after every lean-rich cycle. One of the key factor of this approach [8,9] is thus the presence of a NOx storage compound and the BaO surfaces play a crucial role for the stability of stored NOx species and their subsequent reduction in the overall NSR performance of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In attempt to clarify the mechanism of NOx storage, extensive studies have been conducted by several research groups [10–16] and the results can be classified into two main categories. Accordingly, the NOx storage process is described [10,12] to occur initially via oxidation of NO to NO2 and then the process occurs via a mechanism of disproportionation [11] with Ba nitrate formation and a release of NO in the gas phase. The second storage mechanism [14–16] is based on the so called: “nitrite” route where NO is effectively adsorbed on a Ba site in proximity of a Pt site through stepwise oxidation to form at first a nitrite species that is progressively oxidized into a nitrate. Different experimental [17–25] and theoretical [23,26] studies were focused on the elucidation of the interaction of NO2 with the storage Ba component, and on the nature of the NOx absorbed species formed on the surface of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Among the numerous studies reported up to date, there is a general agreement for the existence of energetically different NOx storage active sites that can be differentiated by the mechanism of adsorption. For instance, the storage of NOx on alumina-supported BaO has been studied extensively in the past several years by Lietti et al. [17] who proposed that the storage of NOx occurs preferentially more efficiently in the order of BaO, Ba(OH)2 and BaCO3. The abundance of the different Ba sites at the catalyst surface was found to depend on the composition of the exhaust gas and extent of reduction. Similar results were also obtained by Nova et al. [18], who reported that NOx storage occurs first on BaO and then on BaCO3, which are the most abundant sites following regeneration of the catalyst. Additionally, the presence of two kinds of adsorption sites was also reported by Rodrigues et al. [19], either in the form of large barium carbonate crystals or in the form of highly dispersed barium species on the alumina support. Similarly, it has been indicated by Piacentini et al. [20] where depending on the Ba loading, three different NOx storage sites were found to exist on the catalyst surface: amorphous BaO, LT-BaCO3 (low thermal stability) and HT-BaCO3 (high thermal stability). Further evidence of multiple NOx sorption sites, most likely based on the proximity of Ba and Pt components, was obtained in the studies performed by Epling et al. [21]. The nature of the NOx adsorbed – species on the BaO/γ-Al2O3 system has been thoroughly discussed in various former studies in the literature [22–27]. Using primarily vibrational spectroscopic techniques and TPD analysis, Szanyi et al. [9,22] have found the existence of two distinctly different nitrate species: NOx adsorbed more loosely bounded to the surface BaO monomers/dimers strongly interacting with the support and NOx strongly bounded to the bulk BaO particles, existing in the form of three-dimensional BaO clusters. There are several kinetic models published in the literature describing the NOx storage process. A detailed kinetic model was developed by Olsson et al. [28] for a monolithic Pt/BaO/Al2O3 system. The proposed kinetic model considered that NO is oxidized to NO2 on Pt sites and that NO2 is then stored on the Ba component. It was successfully validated by comparing model predictions with experimental data obtained during NO2 adsorption and TPD experiments. Moreover, there are some models that considers NOx storage on fast and slow sites, respectively, like the studies by Scholz et al. [32] and by Kočí et al. [33]. In the study by Scholz et al. [32], the model considers that fast NOx storage occurs at surface barium sites, as determined by the reaction kinetics. Slow NOx storage occurs at the semi-bulk and bulk barium sites, where diffusion plays a major role. It is assumed that surface, bulk, and semi-bulk sites differ not only in physical appearance, but also in chemical reactivity. Mass-transfer inside the storage particles was also considered in shrinking core-type of models by Tuttlies et al. [30] and Olsson et al. [29,31,34]. Moreover, multiple storage sites have been added to kinetic models to reflect storage on different materials, such as alumina barium and potassium [34–36]. In the above described models, the binding strength of stored NOx has been tuned to flow reactor data. However, it is a large advantage to measure the heat of adsorption and use this data directly into the models. This will lead to less parameters that need to be fitted and thereby decreasing the correlation between the parameters, which gives stable and robust models. However, to our knowledge, no investigations have been reported in the literature where the heat of adsorption of NO2 over Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was measured. The objective of the current work is therefore focused on measuring the binding strength of NO2 on Pt/BaO-supported on γ-Al2O3 using micro calorimetric studies. The adsorption of NO2 has been investigated by micro calorimetry, performed in parallel with the time-on-stream of the NOx storage tests and subsequent TPD analysis. In addition to this, the impact of CO2 on NOx adsorption was also investigated, since the mechanism of the NOx uptake in the presence of CO2 is believed [37] to occur by competitive adsorption of CO2 and NO2 for the same adsorption sites. Thus, the heat of adsorption of NO2 (ΔH ads (NO2)) was determined over a wide range of surface NOx coverages, as the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was exposed to 500/900ppm NO2 in the absence/presence of 5% CO2 at five different temperatures in the range of 423–773K. Based on these measurements in a combination with TPD analysis, it is possible to provide evidence, as calorimetric verification (i) for the presence of energetically different adsorption sites, producing NOx adsorbed species with different bond strength, (ii) in support for the detrimental effect of CO2 on the NOx uptake performance and (iii) effect of NO2 concentration on the binding strengths. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Conventional incipient wetness impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (171m2/g, Sasol Puralox SBa-200) was used for synthesis of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 and BaO/γ-Al2O3 samples. The procedure of preparation has been described in detail in Refs. [38,39]. Briefly, the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (1wt% Pt and 16wt% BaO) was prepared by consecutive impregnation of the support with aqueous solutions of Pt(NO3)2 (15.46wt%, W.C. Heraeus) and Ba(NO3)2 (99wt%, Sigma-Aldrich). The noble metal precursor solution was prepared separately and after complete dilution, γ-Al2O3 powder (pre-calcined at 1023K for 2.5h) was slowly added to the aqueous solution under constant stirring at room temperature. The slurry was continuously stirred and freeze dried in liquid nitrogen until the water from the suspension was completely removed. The product was then ground into a fine powder form and calcined at 773K for 2h. After that, the barium nitrate precursor solution was slowly added under vigorous stirring at room temperature to the pre-prepared solution of Pt/γ-Al2O3 sample dispersed in a certain amount of milli-q water. The mixture was continuously stirred for 1h and then the slurry was again freeze dried and calcined at 873K for 2h. In similar way, the non-Pt containing BaO/γ-Al2O3 sample (the amount of BaO was kept constant at 16wt% in both samples) was synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation of the γ-Al2O3 with the aqueous solution of Ba(NO3)2. Then, after continuously stirring for 1h the mixture was freeze dried and calcined at 873K for 2h. 2.2 Micro – calorimetric and NOx storage/TPD experiments The NO2 adsorption and TPD experiments have been performed using a gas flow-through differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) at atmospheric pressure. The design as well as the operation of the experimental set-up has been previously described in Ref. [38]. Briefly, the microcalorimetric cell comprises a pair of two vertical quartz tubes mounted in an electric furnace, part of the assembly of the heat-flux DSC Setaram Sensys. One contained the sample powder (∼0.1g) placed on the top of a quartz sintered bed and the other one was kept empty and served as a reference. The design of the cell allowed gas flow through the catalyst bed thus, the microcalorimetric measurements were performed in parallel into the time-on-stream of the NOx adsorption experiments. The inlet gas composition was controlled by using a system of individual mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst Hi-Tech) and the effluent from the outlet gas was monitored and analysed on-line using a Hiden HPR 20 quadrupole mass spectrometer (MS) equipped with a heated capillary probe connected directly to the exit of the sample tube. 2.2.1 Sample pre-treatment To obtain reproducible results, the samples were pre-treated under identical operational conditions, as follows: they were first reduced with 1% H2/Ar for 30min at 823K, flushed with Ar for 5min and then conditioned/degreened with a gas mixture of 500ppm NO2 +5% O2, with Ar as inert balance, for 3h. After the degreening step, prior to each adsorption experiment, the samples were treated at 823K in only Ar for 20min and then in 1% H2/Ar for 30min. After that, the samples were flushed in only Ar at 823K and then they were pre-oxidized in 5% O2/Ar for 30min. Finally, the reactor temperature was cooled down in Ar to the target test adsorption temperature and the NOx storage/TPD and micro calorimetric measurements were performed. The high temperature pre-treatment with hydrogen will most likely remove all the nitrates from the Pt containing samples. It is possible that some strongly bound NOx is still left on the surface of the noble metal free catalyst also after the pre-treatment, and the reason for not using even higher temperatures was in order to not deactivate the sample. However, the integrated total NOx storage from the samples were similar between BaO/Al2O3 and Pt/BaO/Al2O3, actually the BaO/Al2O3 even showed slightly larger storage. Thus, based from these results we suggest that it is likely only smaller amount of NOx left on also the noble metal free catalyst after the pre-treatment. 2.2.2 NOx storage tests in the absence/presence of CO2 and TPD The samples were flushed with Ar for 40min and then they were exposed to NO2/Ar for 90min. The procedure was developed to compare the effects of adsorption of NO2 at five different temperatures in the range of 423–773K, while the duration of the exposure was kept constant. In all experiments, the total gas flow rate was held constant at 20mlmin−1. To determine the effects of changing the NO2 concentration and that of the presence of CO2 in the feed, the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was exposed to 500ppm or 900ppm NO2/Ar in the absence or in the presence of 5% CO2 in the inlet gas composition. After each exposure step, the sample was flushed with Ar for 40min and subsequently a TPD analysis was carried out to 823K, with a speed of 10Kmin−1. Thereafter, the procedure of the pre- treatment of the catalyst (described above) was repeated and then the reactor temperature was cooled down to the next target adsorption temperature in the presence of Ar. The evolved species during the adsorption/desorption process were monitored and analysed on-line with respect to NO, NO2 and O2 content, by recording the MS signals in pressure vs. time mode with mass to charge ratio (m/e) equal to 30, 46 and 32, respectively. Each measurement was performed after subtracting the contribution which originates from the cracking of NO2 in the MS. 2.2.3 Calorimetric measurements The micro calorimetric measurements performed during the NOx adsorption experiments allowed us to monitor the time-dependent changes in the heat flow (HF, mW) in parallel with the outlet NOx concentration curves. In addition, it was possible to determine the effects by varying the NOx surface coverage at the different temperatures of NO2 adsorption in the range of 423–773K, using 500ppm or 900ppm NO2/Ar with/without the presence of 5% CO2. A further increase in the time leaded to the appearance of NOx breakthrough, mainly due to release of NO in the outlet gas and negligible quantities of NO2 and O2. This is in a good agreement with the proposed mechanism of NOx adsorption, thoroughly investigated by several research groups [10–13], illustrating the NOx uptake behaviour of the BaO/γ-Al2O3 system. Accordingly, the NOx storage process is described to occur initially via a mechanism of formation of coordinately NOx bonded species on the accessible surface (S-O=alumina and BaO) sites (Eq. (5)). It is visible from Fig. 1(a) that almost immediately when the NO2 exposure is initiated at 423K, the DSC signal was registered. Further, to analyse the effect of the presence of Pt, as a noble metal component in the BaO-based NOx storage system, the flow adsorption experiments and the microcalorimetric measurements were also conducted over Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Fig. 2 illustrates the NOx uptake behaviour and the time-dependent HF changes after exposure of the ternary system to 500ppm NO2/Ar in the temperature range of 423–773K. Comparison of the data obtained at 423K and 473K (Fig. 2(a, b)) reveals notable similarities to that corresponding to the binary BaO/γ-Al2O3 system. The HF signal was registered as an exothermic maximum in the period of the total NOx uptake. The observed outlet NOx concentration curves follow a trend similar to the non-Pt-containing sample, indicating that the presence of Pt has no significant effect on the NOx uptake process. This is in a good agreement with our previous studies [38] where the noble metal was found to have no significant impact on the storage capabilities when using NO2. However, a different situation is observed at higher temperatures, i.e. at T≥573K. As can be seen from Fig. 2(c–e), the NOx uptake takes place with a much lower NOx storage efficiency than that observed at the same temperatures of adsorption for BaO/γ-Al2O3 sample. As discussed above, the higher temperatures (T≥573K) can initiate the NO2 dissociation Eq. (8), and as a result hinder the NOx storage. Indeed, O2 production, originating from NO2 dissociation is observed in significant amount from 573K. In addition, it is found in earlier studies that the nitrates on Pt/Ba/Al2O3 has lower stability compared to on BaO/Al2O3, due to release by spill-over mechanism over the Pt sites [28], which results in lower storage at higher temperature. This is also observed in our experiments (compare Figs. 1 and 2), where the NOx desorption at 573K is larger when the catalyst was flushed with inert gas after the adsorption phase. Moreover, the heat flow is reduced for the Pt/BaO/Al2O3 sample compared to BaO/Al2O3, due to both the decreased NOx storage and the increased endothermic NO2 dissociation. In our previous studies [38,39,41], we have focused our work on the mechanistic aspects of the promoting role of different noble metals (Pt and Rh) on the NSR performance of NOx storage BaO-based catalysts. We showed [38,39] that the presence of the noble metals into the BaO/γ-Al2O3 has a considerable effect on the spill-over process of NOx adsorbed species on the sample surface (from the storage sites on γ-Al2O3 and those on BaO to the noble metal sites), controlling the subsequent desorption of NOx to occur at lower temperatures in comparison with that of the non-noble metal-containing BaO/γ-Al2O3 system. It was also found [41] that the noble metal dispersion affects the NOx storage performances of the Pt(Rh)/BaO-supported on γ-Al2O3 catalysts. In this context, the current work was directed toward investigating the adsorption of NO2, showing all calorimetric aspects during the measurements in the simultaneous presence of the Pt active metal sites on the BaO-based γ-Al2O3 sample. As shown above, in the presence of Pt, the contribution originating from NO2 disproportionation/dissociation reactions occurring on the noble metal active sites can affect/hinder the NOx storage performance of the catalyst and the corresponding heat of NO2 adsorption. Therefore, as described in the experimental section, ΔH ads (NO2) was determined by using two approaches – “plateau” and “integral”. They are based on the measurement of the HF (its maximum (HF max) or integrated area (HFint )) during the period of the total NOx uptake, when NO2 is completely adsorbed and the signal of NOx and O2 in the outlet is totally absent. In this way, it was possible to measure the heat released due to the NO2 adsorption only, excluding the contribution originating from the NO2 disproportionation and dissociation that occur when NOx breakthrough is detected. The data from all measurements are summarized in Table 1 and similar results are found for the “integral” and “plateau” approach. Therefore, in the following text the values of ΔH ads (NO2) based on “plateau” method is discussed. Note, that for some experiments conducted at high temperature and also for experiments at medium temperature in the presence of CO2, the total uptake was too short to determine the heat of adsorption (these are marked with n.a. in Table 1). To summarize the results from the calorimetric measurements and the NOx storage tests described so far over both BaO/γ-Al2O3 and Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 samples, the changes of the ΔH ads (NO2) (Table 1) as a function of the total amount of NOx stored, is presented in Table 2 . Inspection of Tables 1 and 2 points out that both samples are characterized with very similar ΔH ads (NO2). Thus, the heat of adsorption of NO2 is not influenced by the presence of Pt, showing that the NOx uptake occurs directly on the storage sites. The measured ΔH ads (NO2) exhibit the lowest value, ca. −135kJmol−1 for both samples, at the lowest adsorption temperature. Moreover, when the temperature was increased the heat of adsorption increased, resulting in ca. −178.8kJmol−1 at 673K for the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. These results are consistent with our earlier results [40] for ammonia storage on Cu/BEA, where ΔH ads increased with increasing temperature. The reason for this behavior is that at high temperature only the strongly bound species are stored on the surface, resulting in high heat of adsorption, while when decreasing the temperature also more loosely bound species are stored, giving lower ΔH ads . (8): (8) 3 NO 2 ( g ) + BaO ↔ Ba ( NO 3 ) 2 + NO ( g ) where increased NO2 concentration can result in increased amount of nitrates formed. 3.2 Heat of adsorption of NO2 and NOx storage in the presence of CO2 over Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 The micro calorimetric measurements upon NO2 exposure of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst were also carried out in the presence of 5% CO2 in the feed by using 500ppm and 900ppm NO2/Ar. The measured ΔH ads (NO2) and the amounts of NOx stored are presented in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. The analysis from both set of experiments, with 500 and 900ppm NO2, showed similar differences to those obtained due to the variations of the inlet NO2 concentration without CO2. Therefore, to illustrate the effects due to only the presence of CO2, the measurements from one of these experiments (900ppm) are presented in Fig. 3 . The results from the other set of experiments are presented in the section “Supplementary materials” in Fig. S2. Comparing the data obtained in the absence and in the presence of CO2 (Fig. S1 in the section “Supplementary materials” and Fig. 3, respectively), it is evident that the presence of CO2 during the NO2 exposure has significant effect on the NOx breakthrough profiles and on the corresponding NOx uptake behaviour of the catalyst. The shorter period where a total NOx uptake is achieved can be ascribed to the inhibiting effect of CO2 on the overall storage process. As a result, the NOx adsorption efficiency of the catalyst was found to be remarkably reduced. This was especially visible at higher temperatures of adsorption where the measured total amount of NOx stored at 673K is near 0.045mmolg−1cat which is about almost 3 times lower than that observed without CO2. Due to the numerous studies [37,42–44] focused on the effect of CO2, there is a general agreement that the presence of CO2 has a negative impact on the NOx storage of the NSR catalysts. However, depending on experimental condition, such as flow and gas composition, varying results have been presented in the literature [45,46]. The mechanism of the NOx uptake process in the presence of CO2 is far from being well understood. To explain the negative influence of the CO2, different mechanisms, based on kinetic and thermodynamic limitations, are proposed [32,37]. According to the kinetic aspects, the mechanism is suggested [32] to occur initially by competitive adsorption of CO2 and NO x for the same adsorption sites with temporary formation of BaCO3, which acts as a barrier for diffusion of the NOx to the surface storage sites. However, the formed carbonates can be slowly replaced by nitrates with time [45], resulting totally in the end of the process to NOx storage capacity similar to that which occurs without CO2 [38]. According to the thermodynamic aspects, it has been proposed a mechanism [37] in which the Ba nitrates formed initially during the storage process can be partially replaced by carbonates via CO2, releasing significant amounts of NO, NO2 and O2 in the gas phase. Regarding the NOx storage tests, it can clearly be seen from Table 2 that the presence of CO2 significantly reduced the NOx storage efficiency of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, it also significantly decreases the heat of adsorption, e.g. ΔH ads (NO2) is decreased from −141.2 to −91.4kJ/mol at 473K using 500ppm NO2 in the presence of CO2, as is shown in Table 1. 3.3 Temperature- and NOx coverage-dependent changes of ΔHads(NO2) in the absence and presence of CO2 To summarize the results obtained from the NOx storage and microcalorimetric measurements of NO2 adsorption over the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (exposed to 500/900ppm NO2 in/without 5% CO2) and to illustrate clearly the effect of the presence of CO2, the temperature dependent changes of the ΔH ads (NO2) are displayed in Fig. 4 . The corresponding linear dependences, after a linear fitting of the experimental data, are also presented. The results in Fig. 4 clearly show that ΔH ads (NO2) in the absence of CO2 progressively increases with increasing adsorption temperature. This can be explained by that the adsorption sites on Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are energetically heterogeneous, producing NOx adsorbed species with different binding energies. Accordingly, at higher adsorption temperatures when a minimum NOx coverage is achieved, the NOx storage is occurring only on the sites that have very high adsorption strength. Loosely bound nitrates will not be formed at this high temperature, due to thermodynamic restrictions. However, at lower adsorption temperatures when a higher NOx coverage is achieved, the NOx uptake occurs both on the sites with strong adsorption strength as well as weak sites, resulting in lowering of the heat of adsorption. In contrast to the results for the heat of adsorption without CO2, the presence of 5% CO2 results in significantly lower heat of adsorption (see Fig. 4). Moreover, the presence of 5% CO2 reduces the NOx storage efficiency of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, giving that ΔH ads (NO2) can only be retrieved at the lower temperatures. We suggest that the large decrease in heat of adsorption of NO2 in the presence of CO2 originates from different thermodynamic properties for the reactions in the presence of CO2. Since CO2 is present, the barium (or most of barium) is likely in the form of BaCO3 and storage occurs according to (9) 3 NO 2 ( g ) + BaCO 3 ↔ Ba ( NO 3 ) 2 + NO ( g ) + CO 2 ( g ) Since the CO2 concentration is high it will push the equilibrium towards BaCO3 and this is the reason for the lowered NOx storage observed. Moreover, calculation of the ΔH of reaction (9), using enthalpy of formation for bulk materials results in −177kJ/mol, whereas the corresponding value for reaction (9) without CO2, is −448kJ/mol. It is not expected that the bulk and surface energetics will be the same, and these data clearly show this. In addition, we measure the ΔH ads (NO2) during the initial time with no NOx breakthrough, thus we are studying the initial NO2 storage and not the nitrate formation, since this results in NO formation and no NO breakthrough is observed in this initial phase of the experiment. It is therefore anticipated that the heat of adsorption is lower compared to nitrate formation and indeed this is what we observe. However, the trend that the ΔH for the nitrate formation on BaCO3 is significantly lower compared to on BaO is valid for both bulk materials and for the NO2 adsorption on the surface sites. 3.4 Heat of adsorption of NO2 and nature of the NOx adsorbed species Further verification for the presence of energetically different adsorption sites was acquired from TPD analysis carried out after NO2 exposure of the Pt-containing BaO/γ-Al2O3 sample to 500ppm or 900ppm NO2/Ar in the range of 423–773K. The evolution of the total NOx concentration as function of the temperature during the TPD is presented in Fig. 5 (A and B). The analysis of the TPD profiles, in both set of experiments after the sample was exposed to 500ppm (Fig. 5A) and 900ppm NO2/Ar (Fig. 5B), clearly showed that the adsorption temperature has a considerable effect on the NOx release, due to the presence of NOx adsorbed species with different thermal stabilities. Accordingly, it can be seen from Fig. 5A, when the NOx uptake was carried out at 423K, that the NOx decomposition initially resulted in an evolution of small amounts of NOx in the low-temperature region with a maximum at ca. 522K. Further, with increasing the temperature during the ramp, the desorption process occurred by a release of significantly higher amounts of NOx, registering a TPD peak with maximum in the high-temperature region at ca. 719K. In addition, it is also visible on the asymmetric high-temperature tail of the dominant TPD peak the presence of a shoulder, in a heavily convoluted form at ∼747K. The NOx – TPD of the BaO/γ-Al2O3 system has been thoroughly discussed in studies in the literature [22,38,47–49]. Using primarily vibrational spectroscopic techniques and TPD analysis, two distinctly different nitrate species were found [22] to exist: surface NOx adsorbed species more loosely bounded to the BaO monomers/dimers strongly interacting with the support and bulk NOx strongly bounded to the bulk BaO particles, existing in the form of three-dimensional BaO clusters. Moreover, it is also well known that NOx can be stored on alumina, but that the binding strength is lower. In a TPD study using Pt/Al2O3 catalyst Lindholm et al. [50] found that the NOx desorbed with a maximum at ca 563K. Thus, in agreement with these observations from the literature, the low-temperature TPD maximum at ∼522–560K in Fig. 5A was associated to the thermal decomposition of the weakly NOx adsorbed species, formed mostly on the Al3+ adsorption sites. The major NOx desorption feature at ∼719K was assigned to the decomposition of the NOx adsorbed species more loosely bounded to the surface BaO monomers/dimers strongly interacting with the support. While the shoulder at ∼747K was associated with the decomposition of the NOx strongly bounded to the bulk BaO particles, existing in the form of three-dimensional BaO clusters [9,22]. Further analysis of the TPD data presented in Fig. 5A revealed that the amounts of the NOx stored at higher temperatures in the range of 473–773K progressively decrease with increasing the temperature of the adsorption. However, this is at the expense of reducing mostly the fraction of the weakly NOx adsorbed species on the Al3+ and surface BaO adsorption sites, leaving predominantly the presence of NOx species strongly bounded to the bulk BaO particles, having a higher thermal stability. It should be mentioned that the NOx desorption profile at 773K was not registered completely, showing its maximum after the TPD ramp. Therefore, the NOx desorption as function of the time is presented in the inset (A’) of Fig. 5A where the maximum was registered during flushing the sample with Ar at 823K. The TPD results presented in Fig. 5B, when the exposure concentration was increased to 900ppm NO2/Ar, showed a similar trend. However, in contrast to the data in Fig. 5A, the NOx release was observed to occur with the evolution of very strongly pronounced NOx desorption signal at 747K. This can clearly be seen in the TPD profiles when the NOx stored was carried out at 423 and 473K, indicating the presence of significantly higher amounts of NOx strongly bounded species to the bulk BaO particles, in comparison to those obtained from the experiments, presented in Fig. 5A. In addition, significantly more NO2 was stored and thereby also desorbed for the higher NO2 concentration, e.g. at 423K the storage was increased with as much as 54% using 900ppm NO2 compared to 500ppm NO2 (See Table 2). In the light of these findings, it is clear that the presence of energetically different NOx adsorption Ba sites on the surface of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst determines their probability of being occupied, depending on the adsorption temperature. It was found that this is in a good agreement with the observed temperature- or NOx coverage-dependent changes of the ΔH ads (NO2), discussed above. Accordingly, initially when the exposure of the catalyst with NO2 is carried out at low adsorption temperatures in the range of 423–473K, the NOx storage process occurs both on the available Al3+ and surface BaO adsorption sites. This leads to the formation of relatively weak NOx adsorbed species, releasing a heat with comparatively low ΔH ads(NO2) values (see Fig. 4A). With increasing the temperature of adsorption (573–773K), the NOx uptake process is suggested to takes place via an occupation of stronger adsorption BaO sites, leading to a decrease of the fraction of the weakly NOx adsorbed species and formation of more strongly bounded ones. This progressively increases the amount of the heat released during the NOx storage process with increasing the temperature. The explanation is also in a good agreement with the data from the NOx storage tests by using higher NO2 concentration in the gas inlet composition (900ppm NO2/Ar), where the observed higher values of ΔH ads (NO2) can be explained due to the presence of significantly higher amounts of NOx strongly adsorbed species, likely due to bulk nitrate formation, in comparison to that observed when the exposure NO2 concentration is only 500ppm. 4 Concluding remarks In this work, the adsorption of NO2 on Pt/BaO-supported on γAl2O3 catalyst has been investigated by micro calorimetry, NOx storage tests and TPD analysis using DSC and MS. The heat of adsorption of NO2 (ΔH ads (NO2)) was determined over a wide range of surface NOx coverages. To determine the effects of changing the NOx coverages and that of the presence of CO2 in the feed, the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was exposed to 500/900ppm NO2 in the absence/presence of 5% CO2 at five different temperatures in the range of 423–773K. Heat determination is based on the measured stable heat released during the period of the total NOx uptake, when NO2 is completely adsorbed and the signal of NOx in the outlet is totally absent. These results demonstrate a possible way to measure the heat released due to the NO2 adsorption only, excluding the contribution, originating from the NO2 disproportionation and dissociation that occur when NOx breakthrough is detected. The measured ΔH ads (NO2) showed clear evidence for the presence of energetically different NOx storage sites with different bond strengths. The results from the microcalorimetric measurements showed a linear correlation when ΔH ads (NO2) is shown as a function of the adsorption temperature. Accordingly, initially at higher adsorption temperatures (673–773K), the NOx storage occurred on the most energetically favoured sites, leading mostly to the formation of NOx species strongly bounded to the surface of the Pt/BaO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, e.g. the heat of adsorption was −178.8kJ/mol at 673K. At lower adsorption temperatures (423–573) when a higher NOx coverage can be achieved, the NOx uptake process was found to take place predominantly on surface BaO and Al3+ NOx adsorption sites, generating mostly weakly NOx adsorbed species at the expense of the strongly bounded ones. In addition, interestingly, the heat of adsorption was higher when using 900ppm NO2 compared to 500ppm NO2, showing that more stable nitrates were formed. Indeed, when examining the TPD data for the experiments conducted at 423 and 473K a large desorption peak was visible at high temperature (747K) when adsorption was performed using 900ppm NO2, which was not the case when using 500ppm NO2. The results also provide evidence in support of the detrimental effect of CO2 on the NOx uptake process. In the presence of 5% CO2, the NOx uptake was shown to be significantly decreased especially at 673 and 773K. Furthermore, in contrast to the ΔH ads (NO2) measured in the absence of CO2, the heat released during the storage process in the presence of CO2 was significantly reduced. The measured ΔH ads (NO2) were only ca. −97.8kJmol−1 at 423K using 500ppm NO2, which should be compared with −134.5kJmol−1 for the case without CO2. The measured values for the heat of adsorption of surface nitrates are significantly different compared to the bulk materials, for example the heat of adsorption for nitrate formation in the presence of CO2 is only −135.4kJ/mol, while the bulk material according the thermodynamic data is −448kJ/mol. Our results in this study show that it is critical to measure the heat of adsorption for surface compounds, since they differ significantly from bulk data. Experimentally observed heat of adsorption of different compounds is very valuable for kinetic modelling development. coredata.dc:description: The adsorption of NO2 on Pt/BaO/γAl2O3 catalyst has been investigated by micro calorimetry at atmospheric pressure, NOx storage tests and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). The heat of adsorption of NO2 (ΔH ads (NO2)) was determined over a wide range of NOx coverages, as the catalyst was exposed to 500/900ppm NO2 in the absence/presence of 5% CO2 in the range of 423–773K. The temperature dependent changes of ΔH ads (NO2) verified the presence of energetically different NOx storage sites with different binding strength. The ΔH ads (NO2) was found to follow a linear correlation versus temperature, ranging for example from −134.5 to −178.8kJ/mol for NOx storage over Pt/BaO/γAl2O3 at 423–673K. Thus, at high temperature mostly strongly bound nitrates were formed, while at lower temperature more loosely bound species were also present. Interestingly, the heat of adsorption was higher when using higher NO2 concentration, indicating more bulk barium nitrate formation. This is consistent with the TPD data where a clear high temperature peak was visible after adsorption using 900ppm NO2 at 423 and 473K, which was not the case for 500ppm NO2. Moreover, the micro-calorimetric data also provided evidence in support of the detrimental effect of CO2 on the NOx uptake process. The heat released during the NOx storage in 500ppm NO2 +5% CO2 was determined to be significantly reduced ca. −97.8kJmol−1 at 423K, but ca. −134.5kJmol−1 without CO2. Furthermore, our results show that it is critical to measure heat of adsorption for surface compounds since they are significantly different compared to thermodynamic data for bulk materials.
